questions.text: Which of the following joints is not formed by the structure shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
The provided image depicts a thoracic vertebra, which does not participate in forming a synchondrosis-type joint. The example for a synchondrosis is the costochondral joint formed between the ribs and the costal cartilage.

A vertebral bone participates in the following joints :

  1. Intervertebral joint - secondary cartilaginous joint ( symphysis type )
  2. Costovertebral joint - plane synovial joint
  3. costotransverse  joint - plane synovial joint 
  4. Facet joints or zygapophysial joints - synovial joint

A syndesmosis is a type of complex fibrous joint between two bones connected by ligaments and a strong membrane[1] with slight movement allowed.The vertebra is connected by a anterior and posterior ligament where some degree of syndesmosis type of joint is seen.

Structurally, joints are classified as fibrous joints, cartilaginous joints, and synovial joints. 

Type Subtypes
Fibrous joints
  • Sutures
  • Syndesmosis
  • Gomphosis
Cartilaginous joints
  • Primary cartilaginous (synchondrosis)
  • Secondary cartilaginous (symphysis)
Synovial joints
  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

Related Pearl: Types of Joints in the Upper Limb

Joint

Type

Sternoclavicular

Saddle

Acromioclavicular

Plane synovial

Shoulder

Ball and socket

Elbow

Hinge

Superior and inferior radioulnar

Pivot (trochoid)

Middle radioulnar

Syndesmosis

Wrist

Ellipsoid more than condylar

1st carpometacarpal

Saddle (sellar)

Metacarpophalangeal

Ellipsoid more than condylar

Intercarpal and midcarpal

Plane synovial

Interphalangeal

Hinge

questions.text: The spinal sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve has 2nd order neurons to carry which sensation?
questions.solution:
The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) is responsible for sensory input from the face, as well as motor functions such as chewing. Its sensory pathway involves three branches: the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) divisions. The first-order neurons for each division originate from different sensory ganglia:

1.Ophthalmic Division (V1):
   First-order neurons: Cell bodies are located in the trigeminal ganglion (also called the semilunar or Gasserian ganglion).

2. Maxillary Division (V2):
   First-order neurons: Cell bodies are located in the trigeminal ganglion.

3. Mandibular Division (V3):
   First-order neurons: Cell bodies are located in the trigeminal ganglion.

These first-order neurons carry sensory information from the face to the brainstem. Upon entering the brainstem, the fibers synapse with second-order neurons in specific nuclei:

1. Principal Sensory Nucleus (Main Sensory Nucleus):
    a.Receives input from all three divisions of the trigeminal nerve.
    b.Located in the pons.
    c.Second-order neurons here carry discriminative touch and proprioceptive information.

2. Spinal Trigeminal Nucleus (Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal):
   a.Receives input mainly from the maxillary and mandibular divisions.
   b.Located in the medulla.
   c.Second-order neurons here carry pain and temperature sensations.

After synapsing in these nuclei, the sensory information is further relayed to higher brain centers for processing and perception.

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

Types of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia:

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua
   Cluster headache Paroxysmal hemicrania   SUNCT/SUNA
Gender  Males>females Female=Males Female=Males
Character of pain  Stabbing /boring Throbbing pain /stabbing /boring Burning /stabbing/sharp
Severity of pain  Excruciating  Excruciating Severe to excruciating
Site of pain  Orbit, temple Orbit, temple Periorbital
Attack frequency  1-8 /day 1-20/day 3-200/day
Duration 15min-3 hours 2-30 min 5-240seconds
Migraneous feature  Yes  Yes  Yes
Alcohol trigger  Yes No No
Cutaneous trigger No No Yes
Response to indomethacin No Yes No
Abortive treatment

100% oxygen

Sumatriptan injection

No effective treatment

IV lidocaine 
Prophylaxis

Chronic cluster

  • Lithium
  • Verapamil
  • Methysergide

Episodic cluster 

  • Steroids 
  • Verapamil
  • Methysergide
  • Indomethacin
  • Lamotrigine
  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Indomethacin is effective in paroxysmal hemicrania,hemicrania continuum, and primary sexual/ exercise headache
  • Cutaneous trigger is also seen in trigeminal neuralgia, however, trigeminal neuralgia is a separate entity and not a part of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia

  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein

  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle?
questions.solution:
The tail of the caudate nucleus is not seen on the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. It is present on the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

The inferior horn is the largest compartment of the lateral ventricle and extends up to 2.5 cm from the temporal pole. The relations are: 

Roof - Tapetum of corpus callosum laterally and tail of caudate nucleus medially.

Floor (lateral to medial) - Collateral eminence produced by collateral fissure, hippocampus.

The floor of the temporal horn consists of the hippocampus medially and the collateral eminence, formed by the infolding of the collateral sulcus, laterally. The inferior part of the choroidal fissure, located between the fimbria of the fornix and the inferolateral aspect of the thalamus, lies in the medial wall. 

The lateral ventricle is divided into the body and 3 horns. The locations of the parts are: 

  • Body - parietal lobe
  • Anterior horn - frontal lobe
  • Posterior horn - occipital lobe
  • Inferior horn - temporal lobe.

The anterior horn extends from the genu of the corpus callosum up to the interventricular foramen. The relations of the anterior horn are: 

  • Anteriorly - Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Roof - Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum
  • Floor and lateral wall - Caudate nucleus
  • Medial wall - Septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix

The body or central part extends from the interventricular foramen to the splenium of the corpus callosum. The relations of the body are: 

  • Roof - Body of the corpus callosum
  • Medial wall - Septum pellucidum
  • Floor (from lateral to medial) - Caudate nucleus, stria terminalis, thalamostriate vein, thalamus, choroid plexus, and body of the fornix

The posterior horn extends from the splenium to the occipital pole. The relations are: 

  • Roof and lateral wall - Tapetum of corpus callosum
  • Medial wall - Forceps major and calcar avis (calcarine sulcus

Note: There is no lateral wall for the lateral ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following marked areas in the histopathological specimen shows calcification?
questions.solution:
The given specimen is that of an epiphyseal cartilage, where zone 3 corresponds to the zone of calcification.

Epiphyseal cartilage is divided into five zones :

  • The resting zone consists of hyaline cartilage without morphological changes in the cells (option 1)
  • In the proliferative zone, chondrocytes divide rapidly and form columns of stacked cells parallel to the long axis of the bone (option 2)
  • The hypertrophic cartilage zone contains large chondrocytes whose cytoplasm has accumulated glycogen. The resorbed matrix is reduced to thin septa between the chondrocytes.
  • Simultaneous with the death of chondrocytes in the calcified cartilage zone, the thin septa of cartilage matrix become calcified by the deposit of hydroxyapatite.
  • In the ossification zone, endochondral bone tissue appears (option 4). Blood capillaries and osteoprogenitor cells formed by mitosis of cells originating from the periosteum invade the cavities left by the chondrocytes. The osteoprogenitor cells form osteoblasts, which are distributed in a discontinuous layer over the septa of the calcified cartilage matrix. Ultimately, the osteoblasts deposit bone matrix over the three-dimensional calcified cartilage matrix.

The epiphyseal cartilage is responsible for the growth in the length of bone and it disappears in adults, which is why bone growth ceases in adulthood.

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Corniculate cartilages

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

Manubriosternal joint

Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

questions.text: What are the structures passing between the muscles marked as 1 and 2?

choices.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior thyroid vessels
Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery

questions.solution:
The structures passing in between the superior constrictor muscle ( structure 1 ) and middle constrictor muscle ( structure 2) are glossopharyngeal nerve and stylopharyngeus muscle.

The structures passing in between pharyngeal muscles are as follows:

1. Sinus of Morgagni - It is a semilunar space that exists between the upper concave border of the superior constrictor and the skull base. It is closed off by the upper sturdy portion of the pharyngobasilar fascia. Structures passing through this space include: 
   a. The auditory tube
   b. The levator veli palatini muscle (Option C)
   c. The ascending palatine artery
   d. Palatine branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery.

2. Between the superior and middle constrictors -  the stylopharyngeus muscle and the glossopharyngeal nerve.

3. Between the middle and inferior constrictors -the internal laryngeal nerve and the superior laryngeal vessels penetrate the thyrohyoid membrane (Option B).

4.  Between the lower border of the inferior constrictor and the esophagus - The recurrent laryngeal nerve and the inferior laryngeal vessels.

Related Pearl: Structures passing in the gaps between pharyngeal constrictors

Location Structures passing

Between the base of the skull and superior constrictor

(Sinus of Morgagni)

Mnemonic: PALE

Palatine branches of ascending pharyngeal artery

Ascending palatine artery

Levator veli palatini muscle

Eustachian tube 
Between superior and middle constrictors

Glossopharyngeal nerve

Stylopharyngeus muscle
Between middle and inferior constrictors

Internal laryngeal nerve

Superior laryngeal vessels
Below inferior constrictor

Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Inferior laryngeal vessels

questions.text: At what vertebral level does the part marked in the image lie in a normal anatomical position?

choices.text: Disc space between L4 and L5

questions.solution:
In the right pelvic bone given above the marked structure is the ischial spine which lies approximately at the level of the fifth sacral vertebrae in a normal anatomical position. As the tip of the coccyx is the closest option relating to the spine , it can be the most appropriate answer.

The ischial spine is a bony prominence found on the ischium, one of the three bones that make up the hip bone. The ischial spine forms a part of the plane of least pelvic dimensions or narrow pelvic plane which comprises of :

  • lower border of the symphysis pubis
  • the tip of ischial spines
  • fifth sacral vertebra

The interspinous distance is the distance between the tip of two ischial spines. ( Bispinous diameter = 10.5 cm or 4.5" )

The important events occurring at the narrowest plane in the pelvis :

  • It corresponds roughly to the origin of levator ani muscles.
  • The internal rotation of the fetal head occurs during labour at this plane.
  • It marks the beginning of the forward curve of the pelvic axis
  • This level of ischial spines indicates station ‘O’ 
  • When the fetal head station is at ‘O’, the head is considered to be engaged.
  • Deep transverse arrest occurs at this plane.
  • The ischial spine can serve as a landmark in pudendal anaesthesia, as the pudendal nerve lies close to the ischial spine

The image given below highlights the interspinous distance seen through the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: The nerve related to the area marked in the picture has its root value from?

choices.text: Dorsal root ganglia of T1 and T2

questions.solution:
The above is an image of the left lung with the arrow pointing at the nerve passing anterior to the left hilum. The phrenic nerve passes in front of the left hilum and has its root value from the ventral horn of C4.

In the given image, the left lung is identified by the vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum - pulmonary artery, principal (hyparterial) bronchus, and inferior pulmonary vein. The image also shows an oblique fissure dividing the lung into superior and inferior lobes.

The phrenic nerve, originating from the cervical nerves C3–C5, is a mixed nerve that carries motor fibres to the diaphragm and sensory fibres from the mediastinal pleura, pericardium, and a portion of the peritoneum.

The course of the left phrenic nerve:

Cervical region - both phrenic nerves pass, Anterior to scalenus anterior muscle
Posterior to sternocleidomastoid and inferior belly of omohyoid
Posterior to internal jugular vein, transverse cervical artery, and suprascapular artery
Posterior to the thoracic duct on the left

Root of the neck - It lies medial to the trunks of the brachial plexus in the neck. At the root of the neck, it runs anterior to the second part of the subclavian artery and posterior to the subclavian vein. 

Thorax - The phrenic nerve enters the thorax by crossing medially in front of the internal thoracic artery. Within the thorax, the phrenic nerve descends anterior to the pulmonary hilum between the fibrous pericardium and mediastinal pleura, accompanied by the pericardiacophrenic vessels.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: The area marked by the arrow is supplied by which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The marked structure represents the interventricular septum, which is supplied by the anterior interventricular artery.

Blood Supply to the ventricular septum is as follows :

  • Septal branch from posterior interventricular artery - Posterior one-third of the ventricular septum
  • Septal branch from anterior interventricular artery - Anterior two-thirds of ventricular septum

Blood Supply of Heart :

  Right coronary artery Left coronary artery
Origin Anterior aortic sinus of ascending aorta, diameter less than left coronary artery Left posterior aortic sinus of ascending aorta. (Right posterior aortic sinus – noncoronary sinus)
Branches

Right conus artery (third coronary artery)

Right anterior ventricular artery – supplies sternocostal surface of right ventricle.

Atrial rami – supplies right atrium.

Posterior interventricular artery – supplies diaphragmatic surface of right and left ventricle.

Right posterior atrial and ventricular rami

Anterior interventricular artery

Anterior ventricular rami

Circumflex artery

SA nodal branch arise from this in 35% of subjects

Single Left marginal (obtuse )artery

Atrial branch
Areas of distribution

The whole of right atrium

Most of the right ventricle except a strip along the anterior interventricular groove

Part left ventricle adjoining posterior interventricular groove

Most of the left atrium

Most of the left ventricle except area adjoining the posterior interventricular groove

A small part of right ventricle along anterior interventricular groove

Other options :

Option A - Diagonal artery supplies the left ventricle.

Option B - Right marginal artery supplies the right ventricle and the apex of the heart.

Option D - Left circumflex artery supplies the left atrium and the left ventricle.

Related Pearl: Distribution of Coronary Arteries

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

  • RV
  • RA
  • Posteroinferior 1/3rd of IVS
  • SA node in 65% patients
  • AV node in 80% patients

  • Part of LA
  • Most of LV
  • Most of LA

questions.text: What level of the vertebral column does the given cross-sectional image correspond to?
questions.solution:
The above cross-sectional picture is denoted to be T10 because ,

At the level of the T10 vertebra, we observe:

  • The esophagus enters the abdomen through the diaphragm (at the level of T10), connecting shortly afterward to the stomach at the cardiac orifice. In this image, the esophagus is positioned slightly left to the midline and is surrounded by the crura of the diaphragm.
  • Adipose tissue around the stomach representing greater omentum
  • Nearby structures include the spleen posteriorly, and the right and anterior left lobes of the liver.
  • The inferior vena cava (IVC), slightly right of midline, is mostly surrounded by the liver. 
  • The descending aorta, azygos vein, and thoracic duct are within the thorax.
  • A small portion of the left and right lung are still visible.
  • Small cross-sectional area of the sternum and the costal cartilages of the 7th ribs. The 7th ribs are the last true ribs with costal cartilages articulating with the sternum
  • Predominance of thoracic and upper limb musculature.
  • Diaphragm encircling the abdominal cavity, still positioned deep to the thoracic wall.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

T12

Located in

Oesophagus

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

 

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: The structure marked as 'X' in image A has a direct connection with which of the following structures marked in image B?
questions.solution:
Image A shows a section of the cerebellum and image B shows a section of the midbrain. The structure labeled as 'X' represents the dentate nucleus of the cerebellum, which has a direct connection with the structure marked as '1', which is the red nucleus.

The dentate nucleus is the largest of the cerebellar nuclei. It has the shape of a crumpled bag with the opening facing medially. The interior of the bag is filled with white matter made up of efferent fibers that leave the nucleus through the opening to form a large part of the superior cerebellar peduncle.

The efferent pathways from the dentate nucleus connect to the thalamus and the red nucleus, via the dentato- rubro -thalamic pathway.

Other structures in the image B :

2 - Represents superior colliculus, which receives afferents from the retina and the occipital cortex.

3 - Represents substantia nigra, which receives afferents mainly from the caudate nucleus

4 - Represents the crus cerebri, which contains fibers from the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true concerning the anatomy of the breast?

choices.text: Inner quadrants contain most breast tissue
Ligaments of cooper are found only in lower quadrants
Tail of Spence extends across anterior axillary fold

questions.solution:
The tail of Spence extends across the anterior axillary fold and is a small extension of the upper lateral quadrant of the breast.

The breast lies in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region. It is divided into four quadrants, i.e. upper medial, upper lateral, lower medial and lower lateral. 

Vertically, it extends from the second to the sixth ribs. Horizontally, it extends from the lateral border of the sternum to the midaxillary line. A small extension of the upper lateral quadrant, called the axillary tail of Spence, passes through an opening in the deep fascia and lies in the axilla. The opening is called the foramen of Langer. 

The breast lies on the deep pectoral fascia covering the pectoralis major and serratus anterior superiorly, the external abdominal oblique and its aponeurosis inferiorly, and the clavipectoral fascia laterally. Fibrous strands or sheets consisting of condensations of connective tissue extend between the posterior lamina of the superficial fascia and the dermis. These suspensory ligaments (retinacula or Cooper’s ligaments) are often well-developed in the superior parts of the breast and support the breast tissue, helping to minimize drooping.

The breasts normally comprise up to 20 discrete lobes that contain ductal-glandular tissue consisting of branching ducts and terminal secretory lobules in a connective tissue stroma. Each lobe is derived by branching from one central lactiferous duct in the nipple. The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU or lobule) is the functional milk secretory component of the breast. 

The upper outer quadrant of the breast contains a greater volume of tissue than the other quadrants. This is the reason for the majority of the carcinomas arising in the upper outer quadrant.

questions.text: A professor underwent a left parotidectomy. Post surgery she complains of left lower lip paralysis. Which structure is involved?
questions.solution:
Lower lip paralysis is caused by damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve.

The cervical branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the platysma muscle, which is one of the muscles involved in the movements of the lower lip. Damage to this nerve can potentially lead to paralysis of the lower lip.

The facial nerve is the motor nerve of the face. Its five terminal branches emerge from the parotid gland and diverge to supply the various facial muscles as follows : 

  • Temporal — frontalis, auricular muscles, orbicularis oculi
  • Zygomatic — orbicularis oculi (lower eyelid part)
  • Buccal — muscles of the cheek and upper lip
  • Marginal mandibular — muscles of the lower lip
  • Cervical — platysma

questions.text: Identify the normal anatomical variation given in the following CT image.
questions.solution:
The CT finding in the image is suggestive of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

An aberrant right subclavian artery occurs when the right fourth aortic arch and right dorsal aorta involute cranial to the seventh intersegmental artery.

This artery arises distal to the left subclavian artery and crosses the midline posterior to the esophagus. Because of the absence of a normal right subclavian-carotid junction to pull down the right recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) during embryologic development, the right RLN follows a straight path from the vagus to the larynx and is called a non-recurrent right laryngeal nerve.

Most patients with this anomaly are asymptomatic, and the aberrant subclavian artery is of no clinical consequence. Dysphagia caused by compression of the esophagus by an abnormal subclavian artery is called dysphagia lusoria.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
The marked structure is superficial temporal artery.

The superficial temporal artery is one of the terminal branches of the external carotid artery, along with the maxillary artery. It ascends in front of the ear, passing over the zygomatic arch and travels superficially, supplying the scalp and areas around the temple.

Other Options:

Option B: The posterior auricular artery is smaller and located posterior to the ear.

Option C: The middle meningeal artery is deep within the cranial cavity and supplies the meninges.

Option D: The occipital artery lies posteriorly and supplies the scalp at the back of the head.

questions.text: The marked structure serves as a surface landmark for which anatomical structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure indicates the pterion and it serves as a landmark for the stem of the lateral sulcus.

The frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones meet at the pterion. It is a landmark for the stem of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure), the most prominent sulcus of the cerebral hemisphere. It separates the frontal lobe from the temporal lobe. Deep to the lateral sulcus lies the insular cortex.

Pterion marks as a surface landmark for the following structures:

  • Middle meningeal artery and vein: fractures in this area can rupture the middle meningeal artery, leading to an epidural hematoma.
  • Broca’s area: Located in the dominant hemisphere (usually left) in the inferior frontal gyrus, it lies in proximity to the pterion
  • The insular cortex and parts of the basal ganglia, such as the putamen, are located deep to the pterion, beneath the lateral sulcus.
  • Stem of the lateral sulcus, also called the Sylvian fissure. It houses the middle cerebral artery and its branches, playing a crucial role in brain vascularization and cortical organization.

During surgeries, the pterion is a common site for trephining (making a hole in the skull).

Other Options:

Option A: The pineal gland is located in the posterior aspect of the cranial fossa in the brain. It is located deep in the brain, near the midline.

Option B: Wenicke's area is in the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant cerebral hemisphere. It is found in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus.

Option D: The internal carotid artery siphon is a part of the internal carotid artery's course. Characterized by its S-shaped curvature as it traverses the cavernous sinus and enters the cranial cavity. This configuration helps dissipate pulsatile energy, reducing stress on cerebral vessels, and allows adaptability to cranial movements while maintaining cerebral perfusion.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male recovering from facial nerve palsy complains of food getting stuck between the cheek and teeth while eating. What is the muscle affected in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient, recovering from facial nerve palsy, getting food stuck between the cheek and teeth while eating, is because of the buccinator being affected.

The buccinator is a muscle of facial expression. It is innervated by the facial nerve. It is known as the whistling muscle.

The buccinator muscle is primarily responsible for keeping food between the teeth during mastication by pressing the cheek against the teeth (involved in flattening the cheeks against the gums and teeth).

In facial nerve palsy, paralysis of the buccinator muscle can lead to food accumulating in the cheek pouch, as the muscle is unable to contract properly.

Other options:

Option B: Levator Labii Superioris: This muscle elevates the upper lip and contributes to facial expressions like showing the upper teeth and dilates the nostrils. It is not involved in keeping food in place during chewing.

Option C : Zygomaticus Major: Responsible for pulling the corner of the mouth upward and outward, contributing to smiling. It does not influence food placement during mastication.

Option D : Orbicularis Oris: Encircles the mouth and helps in closing the lips. While it is involved in mastication and speech, its paralysis would not cause food to accumulate in the cheek.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Retinal pigment epithelium is not a derivative of neural crest cells.

Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is derived from the neuroectoderm. The RPE develops from the outer layer of the optic cup, a structure that arises from the neural tube (neuroectodermal origin), not from neural crest cells.

Neural crest cells are a group of cells that migrate during embryonic development and give rise to various structures, including parts of the nervous system, face, and heart.

Neural crest cells (NCC) are present adjacent to the neural tube and are sometimes referred to as the fourth germ layer. It contributes to the formation of many organs and tissues:

In the trunk region, they form: 

  • Melanocytes (Option D)
  • Sensory ganglia
  • Sympathetic and enteric neurons
  • Schwann cells 
  • Adrenal medulla cells

In the cranial region, they contribute to the: 

  • Craniofacial skeleton
  • Neurons for cranial ganglia-Ciliary ganglion  (Option C)
  • Ciliary muscles  (Option A)
  • Satellite glial cells
  • Melanocytes

Some of the other neural crest derivatives are:

  • C cells of the thyroid gland
  • Conotruncal septum in the heart
  • Odontoblasts
  • Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels to the face and forebrain.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesoderm

 

Mesoderm derivatives
Paraxial mesoderm
  • Skeletal muscles of the trunk, limbs, head, and neck
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Intrinsic muscles of the tongue
  • Bones: Vertebrae, ribs
  • Dermis of Skin
  • Duramater
Intermediate mesoderm
  • Urinary system: Kidneys, ureters, trigone of the urinary bladder
  • Dorsal part of prostatic urethra (males)
  • Gonads: Testes and ovaries
  • Genital ducts
  • Adrenal cortex
Lateral plate mesoderm
  • Bones: Sternum, limb bones
  • Serous membranes of body cavities: Pleura, pericardium, peritoneum
  • GIT layers: Lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, submucosa, muscularis externa, adventitia
  • Blood cells: Microglia, Kupffer cells
  • Cardiovascular system
  • Lymphatic system
  • Laryngeal cartilages

Related Pearl: Neural crest derivatives

Neural

Mesenchymal

All ganglions

Connective tissue and bones of the face and skull 

All enteric plexus

Dermis of the head and face

Schwann cells and Satellite glial cells

Odontoblasts (Dentine)

questions.text: The cranial component of the neural crest cells leads to the formation of?
questions.solution:
The cranial component of neural crest cells (NCC) leads to the formation of Conotruncal septum.

The conotruncal septum is also known as the aortopulmonary septum. The formation of the aortopulmonary septum in the truncus arteriosus divides the outflow channel of the heart into the ventral aorta and the pulmonary trunk. Persistent truncus arteriosus results when the conotruncal ridges fail to form. 

The development of the heart begins in the third week of embryogenesis with the formation of the cardiogenic mesoderm. The heart tube forms through fusion of paired endocardial tubes, which then undergo looping and septation to establish the four chambers. By the end of the eighth week, the heart achieves its definitive structure, with separate atria, ventricles, and major vessels.

The heart develops from mesodermal origins, with different parts deriving from specific embryonic structures:

  • First Heart Field (Primary Heart Field): Forms the left ventricle and part of the atria.
  • Second Heart Field: Contributes to the right ventricle, outflow tract (conus arteriosus and truncus arteriosus), and part of the atria.
  • Neural Crest Cells: Contribute to the septation of the outflow tract and the formation of the aorticopulmonary septum.
  • Proepicardium (Epicardial Cells): Forms the epicardium and contributes to coronary vessels.
  • Sinus Venosus: Forms part of the right atrium (sinus venarum) and the coronary sinus.
  • Endocardial Cushions: Form the atrioventricular valves and contribute to septation.

Other options:

Option A: SA node is derived from the primary heart field - sinus venosus.

Option B: AV cushions are derived from adjacent endocardial cells. The endocardial cells along with the epicardium and mesenchyme, form the AV cushions.

Option D: Chordae tendineae are formed from mesenchymal tissue within the heart.

Related Pearl: Neural crest derivatives

Neural

Mesenchymal

All ganglions

Connective tissue and bones of the face and skull 

All enteric plexus

Dermis of the head and face

Schwann cells and Satellite glial cells

Odontoblasts (Dentine)

Adrenal Medulla

Arachnoid and Piamater 

Parafolliular C cells of Thyroid

Conotruncal septum in the heart

Melanoblast/Melanocytes (except Retinal Pigment Epithelium)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy underwent splenectomy for immune thrombocytopenic purpura. During the procedure, the surgeon noticed bleeding while separating the spleen from the stomach. Which vessels are most likely implicated in this bleeding?
questions.solution:
This patient, undergoing splenectomy, while separating the spleen from the stomach, is likely bleeding from the short gastric vessels.

In an open splenectomy, the gastrosplenic ligament is opened and short gastric vessels are ligated and divided.

The spleen is attached to the stomach through the gastrosplenic ligament. The gastrosplenic ligament attaches the greater curvature of stomach to the upper pole of the spleen.

Contents of the gastrosplenic ligament include:

  • Short gastric vessels
  • Left gastroepiploic vessels

Hence, while separating the spleen from the stomach, there are maximum chances of bleeding if there is injury to the short gastric vessels.

Other Options:

Option A: Left gastric vessels: Left gastric vessels run along the lesser curvature of the stomach. It is unlikely to be the source of bleeding in this case.

Option C: Right gastro-epiploic vessels: The right gastroepiploic vessels run along the pylorus and inferior region of the greater curvature of the stomach. It is not a part of the gastrosplenic ligament.

Option D: Splenic vessels: The splenic artery and vein run along the superior border of the pancreas. They are not directly involved in the separation of the spleen from the stomach.

Related Pearl: Peritoneal folds and their contents

The following table shows various peritoneal folds (omenta, mesenteries and ligaments) and their contents.

Peritoneal fold

Content

Lesser omentum

a)    Hepatoduodenal ligament 

b)    Hepatogastric ligament 

 

Hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Right and left gastric vessels

Greater omentum (along the greater curvature of the stomach)

Right and left gastro-epiploic vessels

Gastrosplenic ligament

Short gastric and left gastro-epiploic branches of splenic artery

Gastrophrenic ligament

Left inferior phrenic artery

Gastrocolic ligament

Right gastroepiploic artery

Splenorenal/Lienorenal ligament

Splenic vessels. Also contains the tail of the pancreas

Mesentery

Jejunal and ileal branches of superior mesenteric artery

Transverse mesocolon

Middle colic vessels

Sigmoid mesocolon

Sigmoid and superior rectal vessels

questions.text: Identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the primitive streak.

The primitive streak appears in the early stages of gastrulation, a process that reorganizes the epiblast into three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. It appears as a linear thickening on the dorsal surface of the epiblast in the bilaminar embryonic disc. It is found in the caudal (tail-end) region of the developing embryo.

Functions of the primitive streak:

  • Serves as the site where cells migrate inward to form the mesoderm and endoderm.
  • Marks the beginning of gastrulation.
  • Defines the body axis (head-to-tail, left-to-right).

Other Options:

Option B: Notochord: A rod-like structure derived from mesoderm that forms after the primitive streak and is crucial for the development of the neural tube. Located cranially relative to the primitive streak.

Option C: Neural Groove: A depression in the ectoderm that forms during neurulation, leading to the development of the neural tube. It appears after the primitive streak.

Option D: Secondary Neural Plate: Part of the neural plate involved in the later stages of neural tube development. It is not directly related to the primitive streak.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first to be formed by the migration of the epiblast along the primitive streak?
questions.solution:
Endoderm is the first to be formed by the migration of the epiblast along the primitive streak.

Gastrulation is when the single-layered blastula reorganizes into a multi-layered structure called the gastrula. This process establishes the three primary germ layers that give rise to all tissues and organs of the body. During gastrulation, epiblast cells migrate through the primitive streak to form the three germ layers: endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm.

Cells from the epiblast migrate inward (invagination) through the primitive streak.

The first group of migrating epiblast cells replaces the hypoblast to form the definitive endoderm. The endoderm gives rise to structures like the gastrointestinal tract, liver, and lungs. 

Subsequent migrating cells spread between the epiblast and the newly formed endoderm to create the mesoderm, which forms structures like muscles, bones, and the cardiovascular system.

Remaining epiblast cells that do not migrate through the primitive streak form the ectoderm, which gives rise to the epidermis and the nervous system.

Other Options:

Option B: Cardiac Mesoderm: The mesoderm forms after the endoderm and differentiates later into subtypes, including the cardiac mesoderm.

Option C: Epidermis: The epidermis arises from the ectoderm, which forms after both the endoderm and mesoderm.

Option D: Neural Groove: The neural groove is part of the ectoderm and forms during neurulation, which occurs much later than the formation of the endoderm.

questions.text: During walking, the hip bone on the side of the suspended leg is raised by the action of which muscle present in the supporting leg?
questions.solution:
Gluteus Medius of the supporting leg is responsible for raising the hip bone on the side of the suspended leg.

Actions of Gluteus Medius:

  •  Hip abduction
  •  Stabilizes the pelvis during gait.
  •  Assists the internal rotation of the thigh.

Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus act as the abductors of the hip joint. Stabilizing the pelvis on the femur during walking is done by these muscles. It is demonstrated by asking the subject to stand on one limb.

Trendelenburg Sign:
Trendelenburg sign is a clinical sign used to assess the function of the gluteus medius.
It is positive when the pelvis drops on the opposite side of the stance leg, indicating weakness or dysfunction of the gluteus medius on the supporting leg.
In a healthy individual, the gluteus medius contracts to prevent the pelvis from tilting when one leg is lifted. If the gluteus medius is weak or paralyzed, the pelvis tilts toward the side of the suspended leg.

Option B: Gluteus Maximus: Extends and externally rotates the hip; key for climbing stairs and rising from sitting. Weakness causes difficulty in hip extension, affecting activities like standing up or climbing.

Option C: Obturator Internus: Externally rotates and stabilizes the hip joint; abducts the thigh when the hip is flexed. Dysfunction can impair hip rotation, commonly affected in pelvic injuries.

Option D: Quadratus Femoris: Externally rotates and adducts the hip. Injury or entrapment of the nerve to quadratus femoris can cause deep hip pain and weakness in rotation.

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the gluteal region and their innervation

Muscles

Innervation

 Inferior gluteal nerve

Gluteus medius and minimus

 Superior gluteal nerve

 Nerve to obturator internus

Quadratus femoris, Gemellus inferior

 Nerve to quadratus femoris

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

questions.text: Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure shown in the above image is the oculomotor nerve. The oculomotor nerve (CN III) passes through the superior orbital fissure, which lies within the region of the cavernous sinus. 

Option B: The abducens nerve (CN VI) also passes through the cavernous sinus and superior orbital fissure. However, it is located more medially in the sinus and the fissure compared to the oculomotor nerve.

Option C: The trochlear nerve (CN IV) passes through the superior orbital fissure as well, but it is the smallest cranial nerve and follows a higher and more lateral path than the oculomotor nerve.

Option D: The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve enters the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus, below the oculomotor nerve and trochlear nerve.

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)

  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

  • Emissary veins

  • Emissary vein

  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery

  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV

    • Apical ligament and tip of dens

    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve leads to?

choices.text: Loss of extension of the wrist

questions.solution:
Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve leads to loss of extension of digits.

The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) is a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve. It originates from the radial nerve in the cubital fossa, near the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. After passing through the supinator muscle, it transitions into the PIN.

The PIN is purely a motor nerve and supplies the posterior compartment of the forearm.

Clinical correlation based on location of lesion:

    Level of lesion Nerve affected  Cause Clinical feature
Low  Posterior interosseous nerve and Superficial Cutaneous 

Fracture or dislocations of the elbow. 

- Commonly seen in Monteggia fracture

Cannot extend the MCP joint (digits) (Option A). 

Weakness in the extension of the thumb. Radial deviation of the wrist.
High  Radial nerve in spiral groove Humerus fracture. Wrist drop (Option D)
"Saturday night palsy" due to compression of the radial nerve 
Thumb drop, finger drop
Very High  Radial nerve proper Lesions around the shoulder joint & axilla and crutch palsy Loss of extension of the wrist and hand. (Option B)
Inability to extend elbow

Monteggia fracture involves a fracture of the proximal ulna with a dislocation of the radial head. The radial nerve, especially its posterior interosseous branch, is at risk due to its proximity to the fracture site and leads to loss of extension of digits.

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)
